Name: Getting on the road
Body:
In Australia, laws and driving regulations differ across states. Some states require that you carry an International Licence with your current foreign licence. Other states request you carry your current foreign driver's licence together with a formal translation of your licence into English. 

In most Australian states and territories (excluding the Northern Territory), you are legally allowed to drive on a current overseas licence. You can only drive vehicles which your overseas licence authorises you to drive and you must drive according to the conditions stipulated on your overseas licence.

For more information on driving in Australia with an international licence, click here.

Buying a car:

In need of a car while in Australia? Here are a few pointers on where to go, and what to look out for!

 If you’re after a cheap and cheerful vehicle to get you from A to B, we would recommend jumping on gumtree and having a look around to see what’s on offer. Gumtree is Australia’s largest listings page, selling anything and everything under the sun. With over 25,000 cars for sale, we’re confident you’ll find just what you’re looking for!

http://www.gumtree.com.au/cars

 If you’re looking for something a bit more specific, we recommend jumping on Carsales.com.au. Carsales offers more specific search criteria, meaning you can narrow down exactly what car would suit you best. Carsales is a website dedicated to selling cars (would you believe it) so as a result they offer a bit more: for example you can book an inspection of the car you’re interested in buying to ensure you’re getting a good price on a safe and reliable vehicle. The quality of car is better on Carsales, and thus the price is often higher. However, if you’re in Australia for a year, a reliable car is crucial, and when it comes time for you to leave this sunny land, you can simply sell your car on the same website you bought it off!

 http://www.carsales.com.au/

 Tips and tricks:

 If possible, bring a friend or work colleague with you to check out the car that you are interested in buying. Even if English is your mother tongue it can be hard knowing what you’re getting yourself into when it comes to cars. Having a friend or colleague with you gives you someone to talk with who isn’t trying to sell you the car, and can help clear your head, ensuring you make the right decision.

 Do a lot of research on the car you are wanting to buy! Jump on Google and search for things like reliability, how many kilometres you can expect to get from a tank of fuel, what the resale value of the car is (for when you want to sell it after your time in Australia). You can never do too much research on a car, especially if it’s second hand!

 We also recommend you buy a car that already has registration. Although it will seem to be more expensive, it often works out being a lot cheaper than purchasing an unregistered vehicle and going through the motions of getting it registered. However, if you do plan on purchasing a car that does not have registration, it is important to remember that you CANNOT drive a vehicle on the road if it is unregistered or does not hold a current roadworthy certificate. Purchasing an unregistered vehicle is not illegal, and is often a smart move (especially if you’re on a budget!), however there’s a lot to do before you can drive on Australian roads. For more information on registration fees, and roadworthy certificates within Victoria, visit: https://www.vicroads.vic.gov.au/registration

 

For state-by-state registration information, follow the applicable links below:

 

New South Wales: http://www.rms.nsw.gov.au/roads/registration/index.html

Victoria: https://www.vicroads.vic.gov.au/registration

Tasmania: http://www.transport.tas.gov.au/online/vehicles

South Australia: http://www.sa.gov.au/topics/transport-travel-and-motoring/motoring/vehicles-and-registration/vehicle-registration

Western Australia: http://www.transport.wa.gov.au/licensing/license-my-vehicle-registration.asp

Northern Territory: https://nt.gov.au/driving/registration/renew-your-vehicle-registration

Queensland: https://www.qld.gov.au/transport/registration/register/

Name: Health Insurance
Body:
For working Holiday makers (like yourself!), we strongly recommend purchasing private health insurance, and sometimes is a prerequisite for your Visa Application. It's always a good idea to get yourself covered on the off chance you injure yourself during your time across this sun bleached land. Australia has a wide range of private health care providers who offer a variety of health care packages. For all your health cover needs we recommend comparing a few health insurance providers. You can find links to popular options below:

Bupa: https://www.bupa.com.au/health-insurance/cover/overseas-visitors. 

Iman: https://www.austhealth.com/australian-working-visa-list

iSelect: http://www.iselect.com.au/overseas-visitors-cover/australian-health-system/working-holiday-visa/

Name: RSA
Body:
All hospitality staff who wish to work in a licensed venue within Australia must hold a Responsible Service of Alcohol (RSA) certificate. Responsible Service of Alcohol rules and regulations are different for each state, and unfortunately there is no 'one-size-fits-all' certificate yet. We recommend that you apply for an RSA within the state where you intend to work and simply update your RSA if you relocate. 

Completing an approved RSA program gives participants the skills and knowledge necessary to contribute to a safe, enjoyable environment on alcohol licensed premises.

Face-to-face RSA training is mandatory for licensees and staff selling, offering or serving liquor for general, on-premises, late night and packaged liquor licences. Licensees and staff subject to mandatory RSA requirements have one month from the date on which they first sell, offer for sale or serve liquor on the licensed premises to complete an RSA course. 

For more state by state information regarding RSA rules and regulations, visit below:

Victoria: http://www.vcglr.vic.gov.au/home/liquor/education+and+training/responsible+service+of+alcohol/

New South Wales: https://www.liquorandgaming.justice.nsw.gov.au/Pages/liquor/serving-alcohol-responsibly.aspx

Queensland: https://www.business.qld.gov.au/industry/liquor-gaming/liquor/training/rsa

Western Australia: http://www.rgl.wa.gov.au/liquor/training

Tasmania: http://www.treasury.tas.gov.au/domino/dtf/dtf.nsf/v-liq-and-gaming/840a2d6343b0537aca257d8200177210

Northern Territory: The northern Territory recognises RSA's from nationally accredited training providers. For more information visit: https://nt.gov.au/industry/hospitality/serve-alcohol-responsibly

Name: Accommodation
Body:
Accommodation in Australia operates much the same as around the world. Within the major cities and towns, accommodation is obviously far easier to track down. As you head into the regional areas of Australia you will find accommodation a little harder to find, as hostels are few and far between and share houses are often difficult to come by. Some venues will offer on-site accommodation options, but this is something that needs to be discussed with your employer. The following links will give you information on accommodation options:

Flatmates: Flatmates.com is a great website for finding share houses and flatmates! Easy to use, reliable and safe: https://flatmates.com.au/

Gumtree: Australia’s Craigslist. Ideal for finding share houses and flat mates. http://www.gumtree.com.au/s-flatshare-houseshare/c18294

HostelWorld: Great for cities and towns, but can be difficult to find a hostel in parts of regional Australia! That being said there are definitely Hostels dotted throughout the country in places you wouldn’t expect, so get searching!  http://www.hostelworld.com/

Name: Tax & Superannuation
Body:
Tax

From January 1, 2017, all 'non-residents' working in Australia will be taxed 15 cents in the dollar. Meaning for every dollar a you (being a non-resident) earn, you essentially only earn 75 cents. This money is collected by your employer and remitted (set aside) by the Australian Tax Department. 

Superannuation

If you have been earning on average more than $450 per month during your time working in Australia, your employer should have been paying 9.5% additional to your hourly wage rate into an approved Superannuation fund that you have nominated. If you have not nominated your own fund, your employer will have likely selected Hostplus, a fund preferred by the hospitality industry in Australia. Your employer is required to provide you with the details of your nominated superannuation account.  You can reclaim your super only when you are departing Australia permanently. In order to reclaim your Superannuation you must have permanently left Australia and your visa must be expired. All foreigners on working visas will most likely have had Superannuation payments deducted from their pay- this is not necessarily the case if you have been paid in cash or contracted as a casual consultant. To claim your super you do not have to have been classed as a resident for tax purposes. Anyone departing Australia has a right to reclaim their super and tax withheld, and it is important to note that claiming your super does not stop your from returning to Australia for work.

All you need from your employer(s) is your final payment summary. What the summary provides is total hours worked, your rate of pay, and accumulated super/tax withheld. With this information you will be able to claim your return and receive your payment! For more information on claiming your superannuation visit Hostplus.

For more information on claiming your superannuation, click here.

Name: Rates of Pay
Body: There’s a variety of ways that venues within the hospitality industry compensate (pay) their workers. While some have collective agreements with staff, others work to the designated award, and some pay cash-in-hand. In each instance we encourage you to determine your compensation package prior to starting work. For all information regarding average-pay and award wages, please visit: https://www.fairwork.gov.au/pay/minimum-wages

Name: Visas
Body:
The working holiday visa (subclass 417) is a temporary travel visa offered to people (18-30 years) who wish to travel and work in Australia for up to one year. If you wish to apply for your first work travel visa, you must be outside of Australia at the time of application. 

Regarding employment, the visa generally only allows you to work for the same employer for 6 months. After those 6 months expire you are able to continue working in Australia for another 6 months, but it must be for a different employer. 

If you wish to remain in Australia for longer than your visa permits, you must submit a new Visa application prior to your current visa expiring. In order to be eligible for a second year Visa extension, you have to have spent a total of 88 days working in designated regional areas in Australia completing 'Specified Work'. The Australian Immigration Department classifies 'Specified Work' as a variety of jobs in and related to the following fields:

  • Plant and Animal Cultivation (i.e work within a government approved farm, orchard, vineyard)
  • Fishing and Pearling
  • Tree Farming and Felling
  • Mining and Construction

To be considered you must also meet the following requirements:

  • have completed 88 days of specified work in regional Australia while on your first Working Holiday (417) visa (there is no requirement to do further specified work on the second visa)
  • not have previously entered Australia on a Work and Holiday (462) visa
  • be aged between 18 and 30 years at the time of applying, however, you may be aged over 30 years of age at the time your visa is granted
  • be applying no more than 12 months before you intend to travel to Australia, if applying from outside Australia
  • will not be accompanied by dependent children at any time during your stay in Australia

How do I apply for a second-year visa extension?

Online Applications

You can apply for your second-year visa extension online here: https://www.border.gov.au/Trav/Visa-1/417-. The online application process can take around 20 minutes. You will receive a Transaction Reference Number (TRN). Keep this number as you will need it to identify your application when you contact the department for information about the progress of your application. 

Paper Applications

You must complete an Application Form 1150. The application checklist on Form 1150 details the information and supporting documents you must provide with your paper application. Note: European Union and national identity cards cannot be used to apply for a Working Holiday visa. You must apply using a passport from an eligible country. Incomplete applications may be delayed or refused. You can lodge or post a paper application for your second Working Holiday visa in or outside Australia. Applications can be sent to the following addresses:

New South Wales: 

Street address: 26 Lee Street, Sydney NSW 2000

Postal address: GPO Box 9984, Sydney NSW 2001

Counter hours: 9 am to 4 pm Monday to Friday

Australian Capital Territory: 

Street Address: 3 Lonsdale Street, Braddon ACT 2612

Postal address: GPO Box 717, Canberra ACT 2601

Counter hours: 9 am to 4 pm Monday to Friday 

Victoria: 

Street address: 2 Lonsdale Street, Melbourne Vic. 3000

Postal address: PO Box 241, Melbourne Vic. 3001

Counter hours: 9 am to 4 pm Monday to Friday

Northern Territory:

Street address: 40 Cavenagh Street, Darwin NT 0800

Postal address: GPO Box 864, Darwin NT 0801

Counter hours: 9 am to 4 pm Monday to Friday

Queensland:

Street address: 299 Adelaide Street, Brisbane Qld 4000

Postal address: GPO Box 9984, Brisbane Qld 4001

Counter hours: 9 am to 4 pm Monday to Friday

South Australia: 

Street address: 70 Franklin Street, Adelaide SA 5000

Postal address: GPO Box 2399, Adelaide SA 5001

Counter hours: 9 am to 4 pm Monday to Friday​

Tasmania:

Street address: Ground Floor, 188 Collins Street, Hobart Tas. 7000

Postal address: GPO Box 794, Hobart Tas. 7001

Counter hours: 9 am to 4 pm Monday to Friday

Western Australia: 

Street address: Ground floor, Wellington Central, 836 Wellington Street, West Perth WA 6005 

Postal address: Locked Bag 7, Northbridge WA 6865 

Counter hours: 9 am to 4 pm Monday to Friday

What happens when you've lodged the application?

You can check your visa details, including your visa grant number and visa conditions, using the Visa Entitlement Verification Online (VEVO) system. To manage the progress of your application, you will need either your TRN (Transaction Reference Number received on application) or the password you recorded at the end of your online visa application. If you have lost your password, call 131 881 (within Australia).  If your visa is denied, the department sends you a notification letter advising you of the reasons for the refusal, your review rights and the time limit for lodging an appeal. Your rights for a review of the decision differ, depending on whether you lodged your application in or outside Australia. If you lodged in Australia, the refusal letter advises you of your review rights and the time limit for lodging an appeal. If you lodged outside Australia, you have no right for a review of the decision.

Great- you've got your second Working Holiday visa, how long can you stay? If you are present in Australia when you apply and held a first Working Holiday visa you may remain in Australia for 24 months from the date you first entered Australia on your first Working Holiday visa. 

If you are in Australia, but did not hold a first Working Holiday visa you can remain in Australian for 12 months from the date your second Working Holiday visa is granted. You are only eligible for a second working visa once. 

If you happen to be outside of Australia when you apply, your 12 month stay period starts when you enter Australia. The second Working Holiday visa cannot be extended or deferred. 

For all other information jump online at:

https://www.border.gov.au/Forms/Documents/1150.pdf

Name: Work cover
Body:
If you are injured at your workplace (even as a casual employee) you are entitled to work cover. This is an Australian Government prerequisite designed to look after the employee in the case of an injury that has occurred at the workplace. For an overview of how Fairwork operates within Australia, visit www.fairwork.gov.au. 

For more information on what you are entitled to as an employee state by state, visit below:

Victoria: http://www.worksafe.vic.gov.au/

New South Wales: https://www.workcover.nsw.gov.au/

Tasmania: http://www.workcover.tas.gov.au/

Queensland: https://www.worksafe.qld.gov.au/

South Australia: http://www.safework.sa.gov.au/

Northern Territory: http://www.worksafe.nt.gov.au/Pages/default.aspx

Western Australia: http://www.workcover.wa.gov.au/
